title: Mike Dean interview : Death threats , Arsenal strife and his reputation as a showman referee

Itâ€™s a bright and sunny lunchtime on the Wirral and, first things first, you would never think the man sitting here today has been accused of being a showman, an attention-seeker, or sometimes even worse during a quarter of a century as one of English footballâ€™s elite referees.

Iâ€™d go in at five in the morning, work until two, then go home for a quick change or drive straight to Hartlepool, Carlisle, Lincoln, anywhere, to ref a game. Iâ€™d get back at two in the morning and straight into the factory for five. It was hard trying to do both jobs at the same time.â€
That level of dedication was essential throughout a refereeing career incorporating nearly 600 top-division matches and several years on FIFAâ€™s international list.
Yet he is talking here as an ex-referee, adjusting to a different pace of life and about to embark on a new role with Sky Sports.
He also sounds glad to be trying something different after experimenting as a Video Assistant Referee (VAR) last season and finding it a largely joyless experience.

His new gig starts this weekend when he will be in the Soccer Saturday studios to analyse whatever refereeing controversies are thrown up.
Dean has already had a crash course in mastering the television gadgetry at his fingertips, but he knows the real test will come when a referee drops a clanger. Will he call out people he knows as colleagues, comrades and, in some cases, close friends?

â€œI still speak to the majority of the guys but, credibility-wise, you canâ€™t defend the indefensible. If a referee or another match official makes a mistake, I will say itâ€™s a mistake. There wonâ€™t be any, â€˜I can see why heâ€™s done thatâ€¦â€™ because that way you just lose credibility.

It is going to be interesting. Dean left his role with the Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL) over the summer. He was a popular figure in refereeing circles, described by Howard Webb as the â€œchief pranksterâ€ of the group. Yet, football being football, Dean is acutely aware of the tribal nature of the sport and that his name features prominently in many peopleâ€™s little black books of refereeing demonology.
He will also confess there have been times when he has enjoyed being the guy who seemed intent, almost single-handedly, on dismantling the idea that referees have to conform to a certain type.
Dean, you might recall, was the referee who hid the match ball up his shirt when Manchester Cityâ€™s Sergio Aguero wanted to collect it as a souvenir for scoring a hat-trick. There was the pre-match line-up when Dean started sniffing his assistantâ€™s armpits. Or the night when he celebrated a goal for Spurs, both arms in the air, because of a key decision in the build-up.
â€œIâ€™d played an advantage and they (Spurs) scored from it,â€ he says. â€œI was more than happy. Itâ€™s not a rare occurrence, trust me. You will get guys celebrating good decisions in the dressing room, giving someone a fist bump. It happens all the time.â€
What can be said with certainty is that football is not short of Mike Dean stories and it is largely because of his theatrical gestures, the no-look bookings, his strut and his eye-rolls that a Twitter page entitled Celebrity Refs exists.

Dean accepts he was â€œa bit more flamboyant than the other refsâ€. He says he always had the impression the majority of players liked him being that way. But he also came to realise a long time ago that referee-bashing can feel like a sport in itself sometimes.
He sums it up rather neatly. â€œWhen youâ€™re growing up, you have pictures of footballers on your bedroom walls. Nobody has pictures of a referee on their wall, do they?â€
His first match with the whistle came in 1985 in the Eastham & District junior league. He was 17 at the time and had agreed to referee because he wanted to lose weight.
It was a tricky introduction. â€œHeswall Under-11s against Alex Imps,â€ he recalls. â€œI got myself locked in the dressing room before kick-off. The kids had gone out, the mums and dads had followed them, someone locked the door and I was still inside.â€
As a schoolboy, he was a goalkeeper in the same team as Ian Woan, the former Nottingham Forest winger and now Evertonâ€™s assistant manager. But Deanâ€™s passion for football, growing up a supporter of Tranmere Rovers, was shared with a love of ballroom dancing.
â€œWe used to have a dance school near my house,â€ he says. â€œI started when I was nine and had seven years. It was different back then, 40-odd years ago, because when you got to 15 or 16, as a lad, it wasnâ€™t the â€˜inâ€™ thing to do.â€
The young Dean foxtrotted and tangoed in the ballroom of Blackpool Tower as well as touring other spots around the north west. It wasnâ€™t always easy being at school in the 1970s and 1980s and having ballroom dancing as your hobby, but perhaps a bit of playground ribbing helped shape the strength of personality that became an essential part of Deanâ€™s professional life.
Over the years, he has lost count of all the criticism and sometimes uninformed comments from television pundits (â€œGarth Crooks is the worstâ€) and others in the media.

He can remember the 2009 derby between Cardiff City and Swansea City when someone in the crowd threw a coin that hit him in the face. â€œJust one of them things,â€ he says. â€œI donâ€™t think it was aimed at me.â€
At one stage, Arsenalâ€™s supporters started an online petition demanding the PGMOL remove him from the teamâ€™s matches. Dean had sent off Gabriel Paulista because of an incident with Chelseaâ€™s Diego Costa that led to the Football Association overturning the red card. The petition raised 106,000 signatures.
â€œIt was funny, comical,â€ says Dean, bristling slightly. Would they start a petition, he asks, to ban one of their forwards the next time he misses a good chance? Did they really think the PGMOL would be influenced? â€œI thought it was hilarious.â€
At other times, it is not always so easy to laugh it off.
In February 2021, Dean sent off West Hamâ€™s Tomas Soucek for an alleged elbow on Fulham striker Aleksander Mitrovic. It was the wrong decision and, on the long journey home, Dean took a telephone call from one of his daughters saying the family had been targeted with death threats. Her social media accounts had been found and, among a series of abusive and sinister posts, there were threats to petrol-bomb their house.
â€œIt was hard,â€ says Dean. â€œMy daughter is football-mad, a season-ticket holder at Tranmere. She was 24 at the time but she couldnâ€™t get her head around the fact Iâ€™d made a decision on the pitch and, as a result, I was getting all these threats.
â€œI spoke to the Premier League that night. They said to leave it until the morning and they would deal with it then. But Iâ€™d heard nothing by 10am and, rightly or wrongly, I went to the police station to report it.
â€œI went to Spain for a week to get away from everything and I told the Premier League I didnâ€™t want to referee the following weekend. They were fine with that and a few weeks later I had another game at West Ham. As soon as I saw Soucek, I went over to him and apologised.
â€œThe police found the lads who had been sending the messages. They lived in Ireland, two young lads, and the police had got hold of them. â€˜Do you want to take it any further?â€™ they asked. I said no because they were just kids. If it had been someone older, it might have been different.â€
It is the kind of story that makes you wonder whether refereeing is worth all the hassle.

But Dean also makes the point that this was the exception and the only time in a long career when he has encountered something of that nature.
Most of the people who stop him in the street just want to chat or ask for a photograph. He and his family are well known on the Wirral, where his mother, Janet, was awarded an MBE because of her 35 years as a lollipop lady outside the same primary school.
It is not true, he says, that a well-known referee has to live by certain guidelines, knowing which places can be visited, where to avoid and the potential risks of encountering the wrong people.
â€œIt just doesnâ€™t happen,â€ he says. â€œPeople think it happens, but it doesnâ€™t. You might hear someone say, â€˜Iâ€™ve seen that ref, I gave him a load of griefâ€™, but itâ€™s rubbish. And if someone did shout something, I just wouldnâ€™t make eye contact.
â€œYou know when youâ€™re walking down the road and you see someone and you think, â€˜Oh, here we go, this could be troubleâ€™. Someone might say something, but itâ€™s very, very rare.â€
If you remember the complaints from Arsenal fans, perhaps it should not come as a surprise how Dean responds when he is asked to identify the manager who used to give him the hardest time.
â€œI used to find it hard with Arsene Wenger,â€ he says. â€œEvery time I managed Arsenal, they never seemed to win. It wasnâ€™t my fault. But Iâ€™ve spoken to people from Arsenal since I finished refereeing and they told me that whenever they realised I was the referee, with my name at the bottom of the teamsheet, straight away it was, â€˜Oh God, himâ€™.
â€œI have friends who support Arsenal. Theyâ€™d say, â€˜Weâ€™re going to get beaten this week because youâ€™re reffingâ€™. Iâ€™d say, â€˜Itâ€™s not my fault, you knowâ€™. With Arsene, because they had lost, there was always a complaint about me. But Iâ€™ve seen him since and he was fine.â€

In common with many referees, Dean remembers Craig Bellamy as the most challenging (gobby) player.

He will argue, however, that Sir Alex Fergusonâ€™s reputation as another terroriser of referees was overblown. â€œYes, he would complain sometimes, but I got on OK with him. Jose Mourinho was another one. Win, lose or draw, whoever he was managing, he would always come in to say well done.â€
The interview is drawing to a close and it is becoming easier to understand why the people who know â€˜Deanoâ€™ say there is more to him than meets the eye.
For someone who is often accused of being a showman, it is also interesting to hear him say he has absolutely no interest in joining the long line of referees â€” Howard Webb, Mark Clattenburg, Graham Poll, Mark Halsey, Jeff Winter and on and on â€” who have written autobiographies. Is the truth that Dean is not such a showy person, after all?
More than anything, he leaves the impression of being entirely comfortable in his own skin. At 55, he is enjoying being a grandfather. He has a house in Spain, south of Murcia, that he visits every month. A keen golfer, he plays off a handicap of five and caddies for Lydia Hall, Whitney Hillier and others on the womenâ€™s professional circuit.
Dean was taken off the 2006 FA Cup final between Liverpool and West Ham on the basis he lived within 10 miles or so of Anfield. Was he a secret Kopite? Did he speak with a Scouse accent?

In reality, his affinity is with Tranmere, as a home-and-away supporter of many years. And yes, there are times when he lets the emotions get to him and finds himself angrily questioning the eyesight of the match officials. â€œIf the ref makes a bad decision,â€ he says unapologetically, â€œI will vent my fury.â€
